subject: Re: [junit] performance testing
msgSnippet: ... JUnit-addons test runner makes it easy to output test execution results in whatever format you like. I haven t done it, myself, but you simply add a test
messageBody:
Nathan Coast wrote:

> I guess what I'm after is a mechanism automate the recording and
> analysis of the
> unit test timing data.
>
> From this data I could do one of two things:
>
> 1) generate graphical reports to highlight changes in specific unit test
> times.
> 2) Trigger an alert when a unit test increases in time beyond some
> threshold.
>
> Is it possible to set up junit to record the test times in a structured
> way?
> xml? csv?]

JUnit-addons test runner makes it easy to output test execution results
in whatever format you like. I haven't done it, myself, but you simply
add a test listener that collects the data, then you can serialize it
out using something like XStream.

I know Kent did something like this for his book Test-Driven Development
by Example. He logged test execution speed and test failure rate, I
think. I don't remember his getting into detail about how he did it, but
I imagine it's not that difficult.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
